questions.text: A 17-year-old girl is brought to the physician because of generalized fatigue and an inability to concentrate in school for the past 4 months. During this period, she has had excessive daytime sleepiness. While going to sleep, she sees cartoon characters playing in her room. She wakes up once or twice every night. While awakening, she feels stiff and cannot move for a couple of minutes. She goes to sleep by 9 pm every night and wakes up at 7 am. She takes two to three 15-minute naps during the day and wakes up feeling refreshed. During the past week while listening to a friend tell a joke, she had an episode in which her head tilted and jaw dropped for a few seconds; it resolved spontaneously. Her father has schizoaffective disorder and her parents are divorced. Vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination is unremarkable. Which of the following is the most appropriate initial pharmacotherapy?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

In patients with narcolepsy who have persistent excessive daytime sleepiness despite optimized sleep hygiene (> 7.5 hours of sleep per night and scheduled daytime naps), modafinil is a recommended treatment option. Other medications such as sodium oxybate or pitolisant, which are also highly effective for treating cataplexy, may be substituted or added. Although modafinil is often used as the drug of choice, there is no clear evidence that any of these stimulants is superior in treating EDS, so physician and patient preference largely dictates which pharmacotherapy will be trialed first. Second-line medications include dextroamphetamine and methylphenidate.

B) INCORRECT:

SSRIs such as citalopram can be used in the treatment of depression, which can manifest with fatigue, EDS, and psychotic features (e.g., hallucinations). However, depression with psychotic features does not cause cataplexy and is unlikely to cause hallucinations only when the patient is falling asleep. SSRIs are no longer routinely recommended for the treatment of REM-related symptoms of narcolepsy (e.g., cataplexy, sleep paralysis, and sleep hallucinations).

C) INCORRECT:

Estrogen-containing oral contraceptives are indicated for menstrual recurrent hypersomnia, but the condition is very rare (< 20 documented cases). Moreover, this patient's symptoms are not temporally associated with menses, and cataplexy and hypnagogic hallucinations do not occur in menstrual recurrent hypersomnia.

D) INCORRECT:

α2 adrenergic agonists (e.g., clonidine) are a treatment option for tics associated with Tourette syndrome. However, this patient's head tilting would have to occur multiple times daily to be considered a tic. Additionally, Tourette syndrome would not explain this patient's other symptoms.

E) INCORRECT:

Atypical antipsychotics (e.g., risperidone) are a first-line treatment option for psychotic disorders, which can manifest with disorganized behavior and hallucinations. However, this patient's hallucinations are associated with sleep (hypnagogic hallucinations), excessive daytime sleepiness, and cataplexy, which is not typical of psychotic disorders.

F) INCORRECT:

SNRIs such as venlafaxine can be used in the treatment of depression, which can manifest with fatigue, EDS, and psychotic features (e.g., hallucinations). However, depression with psychotic features does not cause cataplexy and is unlikely to cause hallucinations only when the patient is falling asleep. SNRIs are no longer routinely recommended for the treatment of REM-related symptoms of narcolepsy (e.g., cataplexy, sleep paralysis, and sleep hallucinations).
questions.hint: This adolescent girl's inability to concentrate and fatigue is due to excessive daytime sleepiness (EDS). EDS along with cataplexy (tilting of the head and jaw dropping), hypnagogic hallucinations, and sleep paralysis indicates that she has narcolepsy.

questions.text: A 19-year-old woman comes to the physician for evaluation after a minor motor vehicle collision. While driving down a residential street, a young boy ran out in front of her, chasing after a ball. She applied the brakes of her vehicle and avoided hitting the boy, but then she suddenly experienced generalized weakness that rendered her unable to operate the vehicle and collided at low speed with a parked car. One minute later, she recovered her strength. She was uninjured. She has had several similar episodes of transient generalized weakness over the past month, once during an argument with her mother and another time while watching her favorite comedy movie. She has also had excessive daytime sleepiness for 18 months despite 9 hours of sleep nightly and 2 daily naps. She has fallen asleep in class several times. She often sees intensely bright colors as she is falling asleep. During this time, she is often unable to move; this inability to move is very distressing to her. Which of the following is the most appropriate nighttime pharmacotherapy for this patient?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Quetiapine, an atypical antipsychotic, is a first-line treatment option for psychotic disorders, which can manifest with hallucinations. However, this patient's hypnagogic hallucinations are occurring in the context of narcolepsy, for which atypical antipsychotics are not an adequate treatment.

B) INCORRECT:

Guanfacine, an α2 adrenergic agonist, is used in the treatment of tics associated with Tourette syndrome. However, this patient does not display motor or vocal tics and is therefore unlikely to have Tourette syndrome. Guanfacine is not used in the treatment of cataplexy.

C) INCORRECT:

Modafinil is a recommended treatment option for patients with narcolepsy who have persistent excessive daytime sleepiness despite lifestyle modifications (e.g., > 7.5 hours of sleep per night and scheduled daytime naps). However, modafinil does not treat cataplexy, which is this patient's most disabling symptom. In addition, modafinil is a stimulant and should not be taken at night.

D) CORRECT:

Sodium oxybate is the preferred drug for severe cataplexy in narcolepsy. It lowers the number of cataplexy attacks and improves nighttime sleep, thereby reducing excessive daytime sleepiness. Considering it is a powerful, rapidly acting sedative, sodium oxybate is taken at night. Caution should be exercised in the prescription of sodium oxybate, as it has a high potential for misuse. Overdose can cause respiratory depression, coma, and death.

E) INCORRECT:

Amphetamine is a recommended treatment option for patients with narcolepsy who have persistent excessive daytime sleepiness despite lifestyle modifications (e.g., > 7.5 hours of sleep per night and scheduled daytime naps). However, amphetamines do not treat cataplexy, which is this patient's most disabling symptom. In addition, amphetamines are stimulants and should not be taken at night.

F) INCORRECT:

Fluoxetine, an SSRI, can be used to treat cataplexy, as well as sleep paralysis and hypnagogic hallucinations due to narcolepsy. However, it is not the most appropriate treatment for severe cataplexy.
questions.hint: This patient presents with cataplexy, hypnagogic hallucinations, sleep paralysis, and excessive daytime sleepiness despite good sleep hygiene. These symptoms are characteristic of narcolepsy. Pharmacotherapy should target the patient's cataplexy, which has resulted in a (minor) motor vehicle collision.

questions.text: An 8-year-old girl is brought to the physician by her parents for a 10-month history of disturbing dreams and daytime sleepiness. She has difficulty falling asleep and says she sometimes sees ghosts just before falling asleep at night. She has had a 7-kg (15-lb) weight gain during this period despite no changes in appetite. She is alert and oriented, and neurologic examination is unremarkable. During physical examination, she spontaneously collapses after the physician drops a heavy book, producing a loud noise. She remains conscious after the collapse. Polysomnography with electroencephalogram is most likely to show which of the following?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Periodic sharp-wave complexes (PSWC) are seen in the early stages of sporadic Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease (CJD) if the EEG is performed during the wakeful state. However, CJD presents with progressive dementia, startle myoclonus, and ataxia. In, addition CJD is extremely rare and is almost never seen in children. PSWCs are not seen in patients with narcolepsy.

B) INCORRECT:

A diffuse, slow spike-wave activity is seen on EEG in patients with Lennox-Gastaut syndrome (LGS). Patients with LGS present between 1 and 7 years of age with repeated seizures (e.g., tonic seizures during sleep, atonic seizures, atypical absence seizures) as well as cognitive and behavioral changes. Nocturnal hallucinations, daytime sleepiness, cataplexy, and weight gain are not features of LGS.

C) CORRECT:

EEG beta waves are seen during the wakeful state and during REM sleep. The diagnosis of narcolepsy can be confirmed by the rapid onset of beta waves (i.e., shortened REM sleep latency) during polysomnography or by decreased levels of hypocretin in CSF. Narcolepsy is treated with good sleep hygiene measures, daytime stimulant therapy (e.g., amphetamines, modafinil), and nighttime sodium oxybate therapy.

D) INCORRECT:

EEG delta waves occur during the N3 stage of non-REM sleep. Decreased EEG delta wave sleep duration occurs in old age and with the use of benzodiazepines, barbiturates, or alcohol. This would not be expected in patients with narcolepsy.

E) INCORRECT:

A diffuse slowing of the EEG waveforms is characteristic of delirium due to metabolic or toxic encephalopathies, which could cause increased daytime somnolence and hallucinations that are worse at night. However, an abrupt collapse in response to a frightening stimulus (cataplexy) is not a feature of delirium. Moreover, delirium typically occurs acutely, unlike the condition that has been affecting this patient for 10 months, and would be associated with abnormal findings on mental status examination (e.g., disorientation, memory impairment, blunted affect).
questions.hint: This patient's symptoms of visual hypnagogic hallucinations (hallucinations while falling asleep), excessive daytime sleepiness, abrupt loss of postural tone in response to a frightening stimulus (cataplexy), and weight gain for over 10 months make narcolepsy the most likely diagnosis.

questions.text:
A 16-year-old boy presents for a well-child visit. He reports that he has been excessively sleepy during the day for the past year and often falls asleep in school and while eating dinner with his family; after sleeping for several minutes, he feels refreshed. He sleeps 9 to 10 hours each night during which his parents hear occasional snoring but no gasping or choking. He sometimes experiences vivid dreams soon after falling asleep and has had a few episodes of knee buckling when he is laughing with his friends.
He undergoes a polysomnogram with a multiple sleep latency test.
Which one of the following findings is most likely to be evident on this patient’s polysomnogram?

choices.text: Increased number of periodic limb movements during sleep
Abnormal epileptiform discharges recorded on electroencephalography
Elevated end-tidal carbon dioxide for >25% of total sleep time
Frequent apnea and hypopnea during sleep
Rapid eye movement (REM) sleep occurring <15 minutes after sleep onset

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Restless legs syndrome (RLS) is characterized by increased frequency of periodic limb movements during sleep and may lead to excessive daytime sleepiness. This patient’s history and symptoms are more consistent with narcolepsy than RLS.

B) INCORRECT:

Patients with narcolepsy may experience vivid hallucinations upon falling asleep and awakening (hypnagogic and hypnopompic hallucinations, respectively). These hallucinations, as well as cataplexy, may be confused with seizures. Electroencephalogram (EEG) monitoring during the sleep study helps distinguish these two entities. The EEG recording in patients with narcolepsy is normal.

C) INCORRECT:

Hypoventilation, or increased end-tidal carbon dioxide for more than 25% of total sleep time, may also occur in patients with OSA. This patient’s history and symptoms are not entirely consistent with OSA, as he exhibits minimal snoring and no gasping or choking during sleep. His cataplexy and hypnagogic hallucinations make narcolepsy more likely.

D) INCORRECT:

Obstructive sleep apnea (OSA) can cause excessive daytime sleepiness and is characterized by an increased apnea-hypopnea index during sleep. This patient’s history and symptoms are not entirely consistent with OSA, as he exhibits minimal snoring and no gasping or choking during sleep. His cataplexy and hypnagogic hallucinations make narcolepsy more likely.

E) CORRECT:

This patient has narcolepsy, a neurologic disorder characterized by disruption of sleep-wake cycles and excessive daytime sleepiness. Although considered a disease of adulthood, narcolepsy typically begins during childhood or adolescence. Patients have brief sleep attacks that last from seconds to minutes, after which they feel refreshed. Many also experience cataplexy, a sudden loss of muscle tone that occurs with strong emotions, such as laughter, excitement, or surprise. Narcolepsy is categorized as type 1 when cataplexy is present (as in this case) and type 2 when it is not.

Narcolepsy is diagnosed using polysomnography with a multiple sleep latency test (MSLT). The two key features of narcolepsy on the MSLT are a mean sleep latency of ≤8 minutes and the occurrence of rapid eye movement (REM) sleep within 15 minutes after sleep onset during at least two of four nap trials. Notably, no published data exist for baseline MSLT values in children younger than 8 years.

Cerebrospinal fluid analysis for an orexin-A (hypocretin-1) level should be considered if MSLT results are inconclusive or if the child is younger than 8 years and unable to follow instructions. Levels of hypocretin, an excitatory neurotransmitter that promotes wakefulness and suppresses REM sleep, are diminished in patients with narcolepsy.

Patients with narcolepsy may experience vivid hallucinations upon falling asleep and awakening (hypnagogic and hypnopompic hallucinations, respectively). These hallucinations, as well as cataplexy, may be confused with seizures. Electroencephalogram (EEG) monitoring during the sleep study helps distinguish these two entities. The EEG recording in patients with narcolepsy is normal.

There is no cure for narcolepsy. Patients should be encouraged to practice good sleep hygiene with regular sleep and wake times, and those with cataplexy should learn about their triggers in order to avoid events. Medications for excessive daytime sleepiness include central nervous system stimulants (e.g., methylphenidate) and modafinil. In addition, sodium oxybate has been approved in the U.S. for treatment of sleepiness and cataplexy in children aged 7 to 17.

Key learning point: In patients with narcolepsy, multiple sleep latency testing shows onset of sleep within 8 minutes and rapid eye movement sleep occurring within 15 minutes after sleep onset.

questions.text: A 23-year-old man comes to the physician because of severe daytime sleepiness and random episodes of falling asleep during the day for short periods of time. When he wakes up from these episodes, he feels refreshed. He sleeps 6–7 hours at night. He reports that sometimes he is unable to move for a few minutes when he first wakes up in the morning. Last week, he suddenly “lost control” of his legs and neck for about 30 seconds after his classmate had told him a joke. An analysis of this patient's cerebral spinal fluid is most likely to show which of the following findings?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Oligoclonal bands are characteristic serum electrophoretic bands found in the CSF of multiple sclerosis patients. In rare cases, MS may cause sleep disturbances, cataplexy, daytime somnolence, and hypnopompic paralysis. However, this patient has not exhibited any of the symptoms associated with MS, including impaired vision, sensory deficits, abnormal reflexes, cranial nerve palsies, or autonomic dysfunction, making the diagnosis unlikely.

B) CORRECT:

Orexin (hypocretin) is a neuropeptide that is released to increase the activity of brain regions involved in wakefulness, including the raphe nuclei and tuberomammillary nucleus and locus coeruleus. Orexin is decreased in the CSF levels of patients with narcolepsy due to a loss of orexigenic neurons in the lateral hypothalamus (type-1 narcolepsy).

C) INCORRECT:

Neuron-specific enolase is a CSF biomarker that reflects neuronal damage and brain injury. A transient ischemic attack can present with a temporary loss of motor function and muscle weakness. However, a TIA would not explain the daytime sleepiness, hypnopompic paralysis, and cataplexy in this patient.

D) INCORRECT:

14-3-3 is a protein that increases in CSF levels in Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease. While CJD causes nonspecific neurological manifestations, which may include sleep disturbances, excessive daytime sleepiness, and sleep paralysis, it would not explain the patient's cataplexy.

E) INCORRECT:

Anti-ganglioside antibodies detection is a method by which autoimmune neuropathies are diagnosed, primarily Guillain-Barré Syndrome. GBS paralysis occurs in both upper and lower limbs and follows a pattern of muscle weakness in a stocking-glove distribution, which is not present in this patient. GBS would also not cause this patient's sleeping problems or cataplexy.

F) INCORRECT:

Beta-amyloid 1-42 is a 42 amino acid residue of amyloid beta and is used as a CSF indicator of Alzheimer disease (AD). Patients with AD experience shorter sleep duration, decreased sleep efficiency, and daytime sleepiness. However, AD would not cause this patient's cataplexy. In addition, this patient has no signs of cognitive impairment.
questions.hint: This patient's excessive daytime sleepiness, sleep attacks, sleep paralysis, and episode of cataplexy indicate narcolepsy.
